title: History of Ancient Rome
description: This intermediate-level course explores the rich history and culture of Ancient Rome, from its legendary founding to its evolution into a vast empire.
subject: history of ancient rome

modules.title: The Founding and Early Republic
modules.description: Examine the myths, legends, and historical facts surrounding the founding of Rome and its early republican period.

content.introduction: Today, we'll explore the mythical origins of Rome, a tale that blends history and legend.
content.main_content:
The most famous account of Rome's founding comes from the Roman poet Virgil's epic, the \"Aeneid\". According to this legend, the story begins with the fall of Troy. Aeneas, a Trojan hero, escapes the burning city and embarks on a journey that eventually leads him to Italy. There, his descendant Romulus would found the city of Rome.

Romulus and his twin brother Remus were the sons of Mars, the god of war, and Rhea Silvia, a Vestal Virgin. Abandoned on the Tiber River, they were discovered and nursed by a she-wolf, an event commemorated by statue of the Capitoline Wolf.

Years later, the brothers decided to found a new city. They disagreed on the location, with Romulus favoring the Palatine Hill and Remus preferring the Aventine Hill. To settle the dispute, they turned to augury, a practice of interpreting the will of the gods through bird signs. Romulus claimed to have seen 12 vultures, while Remus only saw 6. In a fit of rage, Remus jumped over Romulus' newly built walls, mocking their insignificance. In response, Romulus killed Remus, declaring \"So perish whoever shall leap over my walls\". Thus, Rome was founded in 753 BC, after its founder, Romulus.
content.conclusion: While the legend of Romulus and Remus is shrouded in myth, it offers valuable insights into Roman culture and beliefs. Next, we'll explore the early years of the Roman Kingdom and the beginning of the Republic.

lessons.title: The Emergence of the Roman Republic

content.introduction: Welcome to the lesson on "The Emergence of the Roman Republic." This lesson will explore the transition from monarchy to republic in ancient Rome, highlighting the key events and figures that shaped this significant political change.
content.main_content:
The Roman Republic emerged in the late 6th century BC, following the overthrow of the Roman monarchy. The last king of Rome, Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, was expelled in 509 BC, marking the beginning of the republican era.

The establishment of the Roman Republic was characterized by the creation of a new political system. The government was led by two consuls, elected annually, who held the highest authority. This dual leadership was designed to prevent any single individual from amassing too much power, a stark contrast to the monarchical rule that preceded it.

Several key figures played crucial roles in this transition. The rape of Lucretia, a noblewoman, by Sextus Tarquinius, the king's son, sparked outrage among the Roman nobility. Led by Lucius Junius Brutus and Publius Valerius Publicola, the nobles rallied the people to overthrow the king and establish a republic. Brutus and Publicola became the first consuls of the Roman Republic, setting a precedent for shared
The early Republic was marked by significant conflicts and reforms. The Conflict of the Orders, a struggle between the patricians (nobles) and plebeians (commoners), led to the creation of the Tribune of the Plebs, an office designed to protect the rights of the plebeians. This period also saw the codification of Roman law with the Twelve Tables, ensuring that laws were publicly known and applied equally to all citizens.
content.conclusion: The emergence of the Roman Republic was a pivotal moment in Roman history, laying the foundation for a political system that would endure for nearly five centuries. The principles of shared governance, legal equality, and protection of citizens' rights established during this period would have a lasting impact on Western political thought and institutions.

lessons.title: Key Events and Figures of the Early Republic

content.introduction: Welcome to our lesson on the Key Events and Figures of the Early Republic in ancient Rome. This period, spanning from 509 BC to 264 BC, saw the transformation of Rome from a monarchy to a republic, laying the foundation for its future expansion and dominance.
content.main_content:
The Early Republic began with the overthrow of the last Roman king, Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, in 509 BC. This event marked the establishment of the Roman Republic, a government characterized by a senate of patricians and elected magistrates. One of the most significant figures of this era was Lucius Junius Brutus, who played a pivotal role in the expulsion of the kings and the founding of the Republic.
Another key event was the establishment of the Twelve Tables in 451-450 BC, which as the foundation of Roman law. These laws were inscribed on twelve bronze tablets and publicly displayed, ensuring that all citizens had access to the legal code. This period also saw the struggle between the patricians and plebeians, culminating in the Conflict of the Orders, which led to significant reforms and the creation of the Tribune of the Plebs, an office that protected the rights of the plebeians.
Important military figures emerged during this time, such as Marcus Furius Camillus, who was instrumental in defending Rome against various threats, including the Gauls. His victories solidified Rome's position as a dominant power in Italy. Additionally, the early Republic witnessed the construction of the Servian Wall, a defensive barrier that protected the city from external threats, further emphasizing Rome's growing strength and stability.
content.conclusion: The Early Republic was a period in Roman history, setting the stage for its future greatness. The establishment of a republican government, the codification of laws, and the military victories under figures like Camillus all contributed to Rome's rise as a major power. Understanding these key events and figures is essential for grasping the foundation upon which the Roman Empire was built.

The price of Nickel boomed in the late 1990s, then the price of nickel imploded from around $51,000 /£36,700 per metric ton in the May of 2007 to about $11,550/£8,300 per metric ton in the January of 2009. Prices were only just starting to recover as of January 2010, but most of Australia's nickel mines had gone bankrupt by then. As the price for high grade nickel sulphate ore recovered in 2010, so did the Australian mining industry.

By late 2010 both Iceland, the UK, the USA and Latvia are recovering after their major 2008 and 2009 banking failures and closures (Northern Rock, Icesave, Lehman Broths, etc). Belarus had a 20% overnight devaluation of the national currency on 2 January 2009. Germany and Egypt were going down with a heavy budget deficit on May 6th and February the 24th, 2010, respectively. The Czech Republic had a heavy budget deficit by 22-09-2009. The banking situation still remains unbalanced, and major banking breakdowns are now limited thanks to the guaranty of public funds in the USA. The Euro-zone is still to recover, but generally hasn't been affected by such profound banking failures, with the exception of Greece, Spain, Belgium and the UK. Slovakia gave money to their folding central bank on the 8th of December, 2009, and Norway’s oil output fell in both 2009 and 2010. 40% of Bosnians were jobless in mid 2010.

Concerning the European 'PIIGS' countries shown on the map : Consecutively to the severe crisis in Greece, some speculation was made against other Euro-zone states, using the pejorative name of PIIGS (combination of the initials of Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece and Spain) to increase the fear and the feelings of messiness these countries may give to many investors who only have an incomplete knowledge of their economy. If Ireland is most definitely in a difficult situation, Italy has strictly no reason to be compared to Greece, with a deficit of less than a half of the Greek one. Although severely affected in terms of unemployment, Spain has already been through such situations in the past (most of the 80's and 90's) without any risk of bankruptcy, and it is important to remember the actual deficit comes after years of positive balance. Thanks to this, the debt refund (interest included) represent, today, less in percentage in the annual budget for 2010, than it did in any of the last fifteen years. Besides, the failing UK deserved more than any other to be associated with the failed state of Greece. But, apart from the questionable nicknames (may "GUK" sound less funny than "PIIGS"?), all this shows how much words and rumours can play important roles in a somewhat serious and full of severe consequences subject : world economy. In any case, UK is indeed not far from Greece in terms of public debt, and surely more exposed than some of the so called "PIIGS". In conclusion, ridiculous rumours ("France out of the Euro", "Spain bankruptcy") and scurrilous nicknames (PIIGS) obviously helped speculation against the Euro-zone, by increasing the panic induced by the quite real and serious Greek crisis. It is however important to remember that Greece represents for the European Union hardly much more than Oklahoma for the USA, while in America, much weightier states than Oklahoma, like California, are in very difficult situation too. In fact, this speculation against the Euro allowed a side effect : the purchase of huge amounts of US Dollars in a key moment of the crisis, giving at least some value to China's colossal reserves (almost exclusively in US Dollars) and allowing the USA to benefit from more time ahead, to carry on going through this crisis, in hope of an eventual true recovery (independent of public stimulus), which is the only viable option for the world's biggest economy to overcome its abyssal financial depression. Since 2008, the "PIIGS" strategy is just one of different attempts : One of the most representative of the precedent rumours was in late 2008 and early 2009, about probable doom-like chain reactions in Eastern European countries, regarding local private banking failures (which, eventually, did not happen to be that bad)... About 37.3 million (37,3000,000) Americans, or about 12.5% of the population, were living in poverty during 2007 according to timesofoman.com. Other sources put higher poverty rates up for Uzbekistan and Tadjikistan. The IMF gave a 3, 500,000,000 loan to Belarus on January the 3rd, 2009, according to www.thefreelibrary.com.

Despite of all this some Arabian economies were doing well. The Oxford Business Group and the International Monetary Fund (I.M.F.) report on the 11th of June, 2009, that Bahrain should see an economic increase of 2.6 % in the fiscal year of 2009 to 2010. Oman’s tourist industry grew, but a dip in oil exports caused a brief recession by May 2009. Saudi Arabia, Quatar and Kuwait were also seeing limited positive economic growth during 2009 and 2010. Surprisingly, The Emirate of Dubai went temporarily bankrupt on the 24th of March, 2009. Abu Dhabi has also saw a heavy slip in real estate sales since 2008 and subsequently prices have also slipped slightly downwards in 2010. Inevitably the crisis has affected all countries in region some ways, but certain countries were vastly affected more than others.

Their economies were damaged by this to. The Johannesburg Stock Exchange fell by 31% in 2008. Consumers hid from the heat in air-conditioned shopping malls and bought more goods than usual summer merchandise like ice cream, air conditioners, fans, swimwear, hats, sun screen, vest tops and pool and beach equipment were all selling like the proverbial hotcakes, whilst unusualy heavy monsoons hit other parts of the nation.

modules.title: The Roman Empire: Rise and Expansion
modules.description: Delve into the transformation of Rome from a republic to an empire, focusing on its growth and the rulers who shaped it.

lessons.title: From Republic to Empire: The Rise of Augustus

content.introduction: In this lesson, we will explore the transition of Rome from a Republic to an Empire, focusing on the pivotal role of Augustus. This period marks a significant shift in Roman governance and sets the stage for the Imperial era.
content.main_content:
The Roman Republic, which had endured for nearly five centuries, began to falter in the 1st century BCE. The Republic was characterized by a complex system of checks and balances, with power shared among the Senate, the magistrates, and the people. However, this system became increasingly unstable due to internal conflicts and external pressures.

One of the key figures during this tumultuous period was Julius Caesar. His rise to power and subsequent dictatorship marked a turning point in Roman history. Caesar's assassination in 44 BCE left a power vacuum that his adopted heir, Octavianlater known as Augustus), would eventually fill. Octavian's rise to power was not straightforward; he faced significant opposition from rivals such as Mark Antony and Cleopatra. Through a series of strategic alliances and military victories, including the decisive Battle of Actium in 31 BCE, Octavian emerged as the sole ruler of Rome.

Augustus's reign (27 BCE - 14 CE) is often seen as the beginning of the Roman Empire. He introduced a new form of governance known as the Principate, where he held the title of "Princeps" or "first citizen." This allowed him to maintain the facade of the Republic while consolidating power. Augustus implemented numerous reforms, including reorganizing the military, establishing a professional bureaucracy, and initiating a vast building program in Rome. His policies brought stability and prosperity, earning him the honor "Augustus," which means "the revered one."
content.conclusion: Augustus's transformation of Rome from a Republic to an Empire had profound and lasting effects. His legacy includes not only the political structure of the Empire but also significant cultural and architectural achievements. Understanding this transition is crucial for grasping the broader history of Ancient Rome and its enduring impact on Western civilization.

content.introduction: The Julian Dynasty, also known as the Julio-Claudian Dynasty, was the first imperial dynasty of the Roman Empire. It began with Augustus, the adopted son of Julius Caesar, and ended with the death of Nero in 68 AD.
content.main_content:
The Julian Dynasty began with the reign of Augustus (27 BC - 14 AD), who is often considered the first Roman Emperor. Born Gaius Octavius, he was the adopted son of Julius Caesar and took the name Augustus, meaning "the exalted one." His reign was marked by a period of relative peace, known as the Pax Romana.

Augustus was succeeded by his stepson Tiberius (14 - 37 AD), a skilled military leader who initially refused the imperial title but eventually accepted Tiberius's reign was marked by both prosperity and turmoil, including the trial and death of Jesus Christ. Tiberius became increasingly paranoid and reclusive, eventually retreating to the island of Capri.

Following Tiberius, Caligula (37 - 41 AD) took the throne. Known for his extravagance and cruelty, Caligula's reign was short and tumultuous. He was assassinated by members of the Praetorian Guard, leading to the ascension of his uncle Claudius (41 - 54 AD). Claudius was known for his administrative skills and expansions of the empire, including the conquest of Britain.

The last emperor of the Julian Dynasty was Nero (54 - 68 AD), who is infamous for his tyrannical rule and the Great Fire of Rome. Nero's reign ended in, marking the end of the Julian Dynasty and the beginning of the Year of the Four Emperors, a period of civil war and instability.
content.conclusion: The Julian Dynasty played a crucial role in shaping the Roman Empire, establishing many of the institutions and practices that would define Roman governance for centuries. Its legacy includes both periods of prosperity and stability, as well as episodes of turmoil and chaos.

lessons.title: The Pax Romana and the Golden Age of the Empire

content.introduction: Welcome to our lesson on the Pax Romana and the Golden Age of the Roman Empire. This period, spanning from 27 BC to 180 AD, is marked by relative peace and prosperity, a time when the Roman Empire reached its zenith.
content.main_content:
The term "Pax Romana," Latin for "Roman Peace," refers to a period of approximately 206 years during which the Roman Empire saw unprecedented stability and prosperity. This era began with the reign of Augustus, the first Roman Emperor, who initiated a series of reforms that strengthened the empire's infrastructure and governance.

Under Augustus and his successors, the Roman Empire expanded its territories, improved its military, and fostered cultural and economic growth. The empire's extensive road network facilitated trade and communication, while its legal system provided a framework for justice and order. The arts flourished, with notable literature, architecture, and philosophy.

The Golden Age of the Roman Empire is often associated with the rule of the "Five Good Emperors" - Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Marcus Aurelius. These emperors are celebrated for their wise and benevolent rule, which furthered the empire's prosperity. Trajan's conquests expanded the empire to its greatest extent, while Hadrian's defensive strategies ensured its security.

This period also saw significant advancements in Roman law, with the development of legal principles that would influence future civilizations. The empire's multicultural nature allowed for a rich exchange of ideas and practices, contributing to its vibrant cultural landscape.
content.conclusion: The Pax Romana and the Golden Age of the Roman Empire represent a pinnacle of ancient civilization, characterized by peace, prosperity, and cultural. Understanding this period is crucial for appreciating the enduring legacy of Rome and its impact on Western civilization.

modules.title: Decline and Transformation of the Roman Empire
modules.description: Investigate the complex factors leading to the decline of the Roman Empire and its enduring legacy.

lessons.title: Crises and Challenges Facing the Late Empire

content.introduction: In the late Roman Empire, several crises and challenges emerged that significantly impacted its stability and eventual fall. This lesson explores the political, economic, and social issues that confronted the empire during this period.
content.main_content:
By the 3rd century AD, the Roman Empire faced a series of crises that threatened its stability. The most pressing issue was the political instability, often referred to as the "Crisis of the Third Century". This period saw a rapid succession of emperors, many of whom were assassinated or killed in battle. The lack of a stable central authority led to widespread chaos and civil wars. 
Simultaneously, the empire faced significant economic challenges. Inflation skyrocketed, and the value of Roman currency plummeted. The economic crisis was exacerbated by constant and the need to maintain a large military, which drained the empire's resources. Additionally, the reliance on slave labor and the decline in agricultural productivity contributed to economic instability. 
Socially, the empire was grappling with internal divisions and external pressures. The disparity between the rich and the poor widened, leading to social unrest. Barbarian invasions from the north and east put further strain on the empire's resources and defenses. The empire's vast borders became increasingly difficult to defend, and the constant threat of invasion created a sense of insecurity among the population.
content.conclusion: The late Roman Empire was a period marked by significant crises and challenges that ultimately contributed to its decline. Understanding these issues provides valuable insights into the complexities of maintaining a vast and diverse empire over an extended period.

lessons.title: The Fall of the Western Roman Empire

content.introduction: The fall of the Western Roman Empire is a significant event in world history, marking the end of ancient Rome's dominance and the beginning of the Middle Ages in Europe. This lesson will explore the factors leading to its decline and the eventual fall in 476 CE.
content.main_content:
The Western Roman Empire faced numerous challenges that contributed to its downfall. One of the most significant factors was the constant threat of invasions by various barbarian tribes. These tribes, such as the Visigoths, Vandals, and Huns, took advantage of Rome's weakened state and repeatedly attacked its borders.
Another critical factor was the internal political instability and corruption within the Roman government. The empire was plagued by power struggles, ineffective leadership, and a lack of unity among its provinces. This internal turmoil made it difficult for Rome to defend itself against external threats and maintain control territories.
Economic issues also played a significant role in the fall of the Western Roman Empire. The cost of maintaining a large military and defending the borders strained the empire's resources. Additionally, the reliance on slave labor led to a decline in productivity and economic stagnation. The devaluation of Roman currency and high taxation further weakened the economy, leading to widespread poverty and discontent among the population.
The division of the Roman Empire into Eastern and Western halves in 285 CE also contributed to its downfall. The Eastern Roman Empire, later known as the Byzantine Empire, remained relatively stable and prosperous. In contrast, the Western Roman Empire struggled to maintain its power and eventually succumbed to the pressures of invasions, political instability, and economic decline.
content.conclusion: The fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 CE marked the end of an era and the beginning of a new chapter in European history. The legacy of ancient Rome, however to influence the cultural, political, and legal systems of Europe for centuries to come.

lessons.title: The Byzantine Empire and the Legacy of Rome

content.introduction: Welcome to our lesson on The Byzantine Empire and the Legacy of Rome. Today, we will explore how the Byzantine Empire carried forward the traditions and institutions of the Roman Empire, shaping the course of medieval history.
content.main_content:
The Byzantine Empire, often referred to as the Eastern Roman Empire, emerged from the division of the Roman Empire in the 4th century. It was centered in Constantinople, a city founded by Emperor Constantine the Great in 330 AD. The Byzantine Empire preserved many aspects of Roman culture, law, and governance, ensuring the continuity of Roman influence well into the Middle Ages.

One of the most significant legacies of the Byzantine Empire was its role in preserving and transmitting classical knowledge. Byzantine scholars and libraries safeguarded ancient Greek and Roman texts, which were later redis Western Europeans during the Renaissance. This intellectual heritage played a crucial role in the development of European thought and education.

The Byzantine Empire also made significant contributions to art, architecture, and religion. The empire was instrumental in the spread of Christianity, and its religious art and architecture, such as the iconic Hagia Sophia, had a profound impact on both Eastern and Western Christian traditions. Additionally, the Byzantine legal system, based on Roman law, influenced the development of legal codes in various European countries.

Politically, the Byzantine Empire served as a bulwark against external threats, particularly from the east. Its military strategies and diplomatic efforts helped to protect Europe from invasions by various groups, including the Persians, Arabs, and later the Ottomans. This defensive role allowed Western Europe to develop relatively unhindered during the early
content.conclusion: In conclusion, the Byzantine Empire played a pivotal role in preserving and transmitting the legacy of Rome. Its contributions to culture, law, religion, and politics have had a lasting impact on European history and continue to influence the modern world.
